issue.title: Feet drift when standing due commit #1565dbd
Feet drift when standing due commit #1565dbd

content.raw:
[This drcsim pull request contains proposed changes to feet surface contact properties](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/269/update-foot-contact-with-more-realistic/diff).

Making Atlas feet contacts softer should:

1.  Reduce feet drift rate while standing from 28.8mm/min to about 2.7mm/minute in the -x-direction after starting up `atlas_sandia_hands.launch`.  See attached [before](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue-attachment/680/osrf/gazebo/1367978834.9/680/feet_drift_odom_ground_truth_1.png) and [after](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue-attachment/680/osrf/gazebo/1367978835.45/680/feet_drift_odom_ground_truth_2.png).
1.  Reduce joint velocity spikes.  See attached [before](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue-attachment/680/osrf/gazebo/1367978360.66/680/joint_velocity_noise_1.png) and [after](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue-attachment/680/osrf/gazebo/1367978360.95/680/joint_velocity_noise_2.png).
content.html:
This drcsim pull request contains proposed changes to feet surface contact properties.

Making Atlas feet contacts softer should:

  1. Reduce feet drift rate while standing from 28.8mm/min to about 2.7mm/minute in the -x-direction after starting up atlas_sandia_hands.launch. See attached before and after.
  2. Reduce joint velocity spikes. See attached before and after.

Feet drift when standing due commit #1565dbd

content.raw: This patch makes our walking algorithm fail within a few steps, the foot sink in the ground a lot and it throws of our state estimation. We had no problems with the physics before the random_row_reordering patch.
content.html: This patch makes our walking algorithm fail within a few steps, the foot sink in the ground a lot and it throws of our state estimation. We had no problems with the physics before the random_row_reordering patch.

issue.title: Feet drift when standing due commit #1565dbd

content.raw:
The `random_row_reordering` patch (pull request #494) improves contact solution. But the added realism has the unfortunate side effect of making drift worse, just the everyday trade-off between accuracy and performance :)

To reiterate, what pull request #494 did was:

 - Reduce contact SOR by factor of 2 (current setting is 1.4, so it is 0.7 for contacts).  This should add to the realism of the contact physics, whereas with SOR of 1.4 for contacts, the solver was over-correcting.
 - Disables random constraint row reordering.  The randomized reordering scrambles the order in which contact normal and tangential (friction) forces are solved every 7 iterations (don't ask my why 7 :), so friction forces could be updated in the Gauss Seidel sweep before the normal force is updated in the same cycle.  This yields less realistic friction force, typically larger, leading to the slower drift.

The unfortunate *beneficial-side-effect* of constraint row reordering went away after pull request #494, which is why I think this issue on contact drift is raised.

In this case, to recover better foot drift behavior, a softer contact is required.  A plot of drift rate (mm/minute y-axis) vs. contact-stiffness-kp (N/m x-axis) is below:

![drift rate (mm/min) vs. stiffness kp (N/m)](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue-attachment/680/osrf/gazebo/1368039847.18/680/contact_drift_rate_vs_kp_1e6.png)

As we decrease kp, there's a sharp drop on drift rate at around kp = 3e6 N/m, and it decreases somewhat linearly after that.  I've updated pull request to kp = 1e6 N/m, which should reproduce similar drift rate to what we had before pull request #494, but the stiffness change is not so drastic.  We can put off approximating rubber stiffness until after VRC.
content.html:
The random_row_reordering patch (pull request #494) improves contact solution. But the added realism has the unfortunate side effect of making drift worse, just the everyday trade-off between accuracy and performance :)

To reiterate, what pull request #494 did was:

  • Reduce contact SOR by factor of 2 (current setting is 1.4, so it is 0.7 for contacts). This should add to the realism of the contact physics, whereas with SOR of 1.4 for contacts, the solver was over-correcting.
  • Disables random constraint row reordering. The randomized reordering scrambles the order in which contact normal and tangential (friction) forces are solved every 7 iterations (don't ask my why 7 :), so friction forces could be updated in the Gauss Seidel sweep before the normal force is updated in the same cycle. This yields less realistic friction force, typically larger, leading to the slower drift.

The unfortunate beneficial-side-effect of constraint row reordering went away after pull request #494, which is why I think this issue on contact drift is raised.

In this case, to recover better foot drift behavior, a softer contact is required. A plot of drift rate (mm/minute y-axis) vs. contact-stiffness-kp (N/m x-axis) is below:

As we decrease kp, there's a sharp drop on drift rate at around kp = 3e6 N/m, and it decreases somewhat linearly after that. I've updated pull request to kp = 1e6 N/m, which should reproduce similar drift rate to what we had before pull request #494, but the stiffness change is not so drastic. We can put off approximating rubber stiffness until after VRC.

issue.title: Feet drift when standing due commit #1565dbd
Feet drift when standing due commit #1565dbd

content.raw:
Copy and pasting Emo's comment [from the forum](http://www.theroboticschallenge.org/forum/default.aspx?Function_fst=ViewThread&ThreadID_fin=263):


Good idea, but this points to a larger concern. It is taking so much tweaking of springs, dampers, friction coefficients and ODE-specific fudge factors to get the default simulation to be plausible. In the VRC, you are planning to simulate mud and slippery ground and who knows what else. In principle you could do this by changing only the corresponding parameter, but in practice this may undo the careful tweaking that went into the default model.  And unlike the default model, you cannot tell us what the modified parameters are so we cannot experiment in advance and complain that the simulation is unstable... and you cannot experiment either because you don't have our controllers... and if some teams gave you their controllers in advance so you can tweak the simulation accordingly, this will be grossly unfair to the teams that did not give you their controllers (say because they don't have them yet:)
content.html:
Copy and pasting Emo's comment from the forum:

Good idea, but this points to a larger concern. It is taking so much tweaking of springs, dampers, friction coefficients and ODE-specific fudge factors to get the default simulation to be plausible. In the VRC, you are planning to simulate mud and slippery ground and who knows what else. In principle you could do this by changing only the corresponding parameter, but in practice this may undo the careful tweaking that went into the default model. And unlike the default model, you cannot tell us what the modified parameters are so we cannot experiment in advance and complain that the simulation is unstable... and you cannot experiment either because you don't have our controllers... and if some teams gave you their controllers in advance so you can tweak the simulation accordingly, this will be grossly unfair to the teams that did not give you their controllers (say because they don't have them yet:)

issue.title: Feet drift when standing due commit #1565dbd

content.raw:
To try and respond to Emo's concerns,

- (Emo) Good idea, but this points to a larger concern. It is taking so much tweaking of springs, dampers, friction coefficients and ODE-specific fudge factors to get the default simulation to be plausible.  In the VRC, you are planning to simulate mud and slippery ground and who knows what else. In principle you could do this by changing only the corresponding parameter,...
    - (John) the main change proposed here is a material property adjustment, i.e. stiffness and damping coefficient for feet contacts, they should be unrelated to the underlying solver.  In principle, we try to base all solver calculations on basic dynamics, i.e. at some point it all boils down to `f=ma` :).  If there's any confusion on specific *fudge-factors* that raises concern, please bring them up for further discussion.
- ... but in practice this may undo the careful tweaking that went into the default model. ...
    - (John) Agreed, this change has unfortunate side-effect of potentially un-tuning team's controllers.  If the proposed change has too much of an impact on team's performance, alternate strategies will be devised; one of which could be simply not including this modification.  That said, if teams are able to adopt the changes proposed here (or some compromise), the end result is simulation of a slightly more realistic robot.
- ... And unlike the default model, you cannot tell us what the modified parameters are so we cannot experiment in advance and complain that the simulation is unstable...
    - (John)  I'll give it a shot at explaining changes here... the modified parameters are listed below, ***first two*** have dominant dynamics effects, while the `last two` should have smaller impact:
        - ***kp***:  contact spring stiffness.  Proportionality constant mapping *compression* at collision site to force-due-to-compression.  The amount of *compression* is determined by collision geometry interpenetration depth at each collision.  It's unit is force per distance (N/m).
        - ***kd***:  damping coefficient.  Similar to collision stiffness, this term creates a viscous damping force proportional to rate of change of interpenetration depth.  Its unit is force per rate of change of distance (N/(m/s)).
        - `mu1`, `mu2`:  friction coefficients are raised from 0.9 to 1.0 to help reduce drift.  (Note:  current friction cone is approximate by a friction pyramid.  Wher `mu1` and `mu2` defines the size of the pyramid.  On Atlas, `mu1` is always applied along the robot home x-axis (i.e. heel-to-toe direction), `mu2` is orthogonal to `mu1`).
        - `minDepth`:  margin of interpenetration before stiffness parameter takes effect.  For example, if `minDepth = 0.003m`, and interpenetration is less then 3mm, then stiffness coefficient is effectively 0, contact is solved as a pure inelastic collision with damping.
- ... and you cannot experiment either because you don't have our controllers... and if some teams gave you their controllers in advance so you can tweak the simulation accordingly, this will be grossly unfair to the teams that did not give you their controllers (say because they don't have them yet:)
    - (John)  Agreed.


Thank you for your feedback.

Best,
John
content.html:
To try and respond to Emo's concerns,

  • (Emo) Good idea, but this points to a larger concern. It is taking so much tweaking of springs, dampers, friction coefficients and ODE-specific fudge factors to get the default simulation to be plausible. In the VRC, you are planning to simulate mud and slippery ground and who knows what else. In principle you could do this by changing only the corresponding parameter,...
    • (John) the main change proposed here is a material property adjustment, i.e. stiffness and damping coefficient for feet contacts, they should be unrelated to the underlying solver. In principle, we try to base all solver calculations on basic dynamics, i.e. at some point it all boils down to f=ma :). If there's any confusion on specific fudge-factors that raises concern, please bring them up for further discussion.
  • ... but in practice this may undo the careful tweaking that went into the default model. ...
    • (John) Agreed, this change has unfortunate side-effect of potentially un-tuning team's controllers. If the proposed change has too much of an impact on team's performance, alternate strategies will be devised; one of which could be simply not including this modification. That said, if teams are able to adopt the changes proposed here (or some compromise), the end result is simulation of a slightly more realistic robot.
  • ... And unlike the default model, you cannot tell us what the modified parameters are so we cannot experiment in advance and complain that the simulation is unstable...
    • (John) I'll give it a shot at explaining changes here... the modified parameters are listed below, first two have dominant dynamics effects, while the last two should have smaller impact:
      • kp: contact spring stiffness. Proportionality constant mapping compression at collision site to force-due-to-compression. The amount of compression is determined by collision geometry interpenetration depth at each collision. It's unit is force per distance (N/m).
      • kd: damping coefficient. Similar to collision stiffness, this term creates a viscous damping force proportional to rate of change of interpenetration depth. Its unit is force per rate of change of distance (N/(m/s)).
      • mu1, mu2: friction coefficients are raised from 0.9 to 1.0 to help reduce drift. (Note: current friction cone is approximate by a friction pyramid. Wher mu1 and mu2 defines the size of the pyramid. On Atlas, mu1 is always applied along the robot home x-axis (i.e. heel-to-toe direction), mu2 is orthogonal to mu1).
      • minDepth: margin of interpenetration before stiffness parameter takes effect. For example, if minDepth = 0.003m, and interpenetration is less then 3mm, then stiffness coefficient is effectively 0, contact is solved as a pure inelastic collision with damping.
  • ... and you cannot experiment either because you don't have our controllers... and if some teams gave you their controllers in advance so you can tweak the simulation accordingly, this will be grossly unfair to the teams that did not give you their controllers (say because they don't have them yet:)
    • (John) Agreed.

Thank you for your feedback.

Best, John

Scott, Team MIT

issue.title: Feet drift when standing due commit #1565dbd
Feet drift when standing due commit #1565dbd

content.raw:
Before considering other options here, I just wanted to double check some details.

I'll admit, the original proposed stiffness change in pull request #269 might be way [too soft at 160.2 kN/m](http://youtu.be/v8lvYwFp43M), I've since updated pull request to a [stiffer contact at 1,000 kN/m](http://youtu.be/ffN3TtGLH0Q), which is 1/6 of the original stiffness (6,000 kN/m), and has an improved drift rate.  Can you confirm that you are testing with 1,000 kN/m stiffness and not 160.2 kN/m stiffness?

To check, take a look at
~~~
/usr/share/drcsim-2.5/gazebo_models/atlas_description/atlas_sandia_hands/atlas_sandia_hands.urdf
~~~
and make sure around line 4237, the blocks look like below:
~~~
  <gazebo reference="r_foot">
    <!-- kp and kd for rubber -->
    <kp>1000000.0</kp>
    <kd>100.0</kd>
    <mu1>1.0</mu1>
    <mu2>1.0</mu2>
    <fdir1>1 0 0</fdir1>
    <maxVel>1.0</maxVel>
    <minDepth>0.00</minDepth>
  </gazebo>
  <gazebo reference="l_foot">
    <kp>1000000.0</kp>
    <kd>100.0</kd>
    <mu1>1.0</mu1>
    <mu2>1.0</mu2>
    <fdir1>1 0 0</fdir1>
    <maxVel>1.0</maxVel>
    <minDepth>0.00</minDepth>
  </gazebo>
~~~

Plots of foot force torque and imu sensor readings during BDI static walk are below:

Foot original contact stiffness kp = 6000 kN/m:
![6000 kN/m](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue-attachment/680/osrf/gazebo/1368152275.32/680/foot_stiffness_6000000.png)


Old proposal with foot contact stiffness kp = 160.2 kN/m, initial peak of z-force at foot contact got "smoothed out" (3rd row down, green lines):
![160.2 kN/m](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue-attachment/680/osrf/gazebo/1368152271.94/680/foot_stiffness_160200.png)


Here's the new proposed foot contact stiffness kp = 1000 kN/m:
![1000 kN/m](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue-attachment/680/osrf/gazebo/1368152274.09/680/foot_stiffness_1000000.png)


I'm resisting putting back random row reorder because I believe it was by luck of draw that the drift rate was lower before pull request #494.  The higher overshoots in contact force resolution and  mixing the constraint solution order (not solving contact normals first) happens to reduce drift in this particular simulation scenario.
I just wanted to double check to make sure we're not making decisions based on cmake failing to regenerate updated urdf via xacros at compile time.

thanks.
content.html:
Before considering other options here, I just wanted to double check some details.

I'll admit, the original proposed stiffness change in pull request #269 might be way too soft at 160.2 kN/m, I've since updated pull request to a stiffer contact at 1,000 kN/m, which is 1/6 of the original stiffness (6,000 kN/m), and has an improved drift rate.  Can you confirm that you are testing with 1,000 kN/m stiffness and not 160.2 kN/m stiffness?

To check, take a look at

/usr/share/drcsim-2.5/gazebo_models/atlas_description/atlas_sandia_hands/atlas_sandia_hands.urdf

and make sure around line 4237, the blocks look like below:

  <gazebo reference="r_foot">
    <!-- kp and kd for rubber -->
    <kp>1000000.0</kp>
    <kd>100.0</kd>
    <mu1>1.0</mu1>
    <mu2>1.0</mu2>
    <fdir1>1 0 0</fdir1>
    <maxVel>1.0</maxVel>
    <minDepth>0.00</minDepth>
  </gazebo>
  <gazebo reference="l_foot">
    <kp>1000000.0</kp>
    <kd>100.0</kd>
    <mu1>1.0</mu1>
    <mu2>1.0</mu2>
    <fdir1>1 0 0</fdir1>
    <maxVel>1.0</maxVel>
    <minDepth>0.00</minDepth>
  </gazebo>

Plots of foot force torque and imu sensor readings during BDI static walk are below:

Foot original contact stiffness kp = 6000 kN/m:

Old proposal with foot contact stiffness kp = 160.2 kN/m, initial peak of z-force at foot contact got "smoothed out" (3rd row down, green lines):

Here's the new proposed foot contact stiffness kp = 1000 kN/m:

I'm resisting putting back random row reorder because I believe it was by luck of draw that the drift rate was lower before pull request #494.  The higher overshoots in contact force resolution and  mixing the constraint solution order (not solving contact normals first) happens to reduce drift in this particular simulation scenario. I just wanted to double check to make sure we're not making decisions based on cmake failing to regenerate updated urdf via xacros at compile time.

thanks.

issue.title: Feet drift when standing due commit #1565dbd

content.raw:
Drift should be addressed and preferably be zero in the simulation (just like the real world). When doing grasping tasks (hose, getting in the car), having all the objects drift randomly with respect to each other will throw control a lot and is not realistic at all. 

We'll do some more tests with the new ground contact model parameters in this pull request tomorrow and see if there are regressions compared to the qualification parameters.
content.html:
Drift should be addressed and preferably be zero in the simulation (just like the real world). When doing grasping tasks (hose, getting in the car), having all the objects drift randomly with respect to each other will throw control a lot and is not realistic at all.

We'll do some more tests with the new ground contact model parameters in this pull request tomorrow and see if there are regressions compared to the qualification parameters.

issue.title: Feet drift when standing due commit #1565dbd

content.raw:
Still seeing about 0.34 radians/minute (~ 20 degrees/minute)  rotation of the feet when standing (we do not apply any control torques on the hip in our controller except when rotating the upper body).

This is with roslaunch atlas_utils atlas_sandia_hands.launch
content.html:
Still seeing about 0.34 radians/minute (~ 20 degrees/minute) rotation of the feet when standing (we do not apply any control torques on the hip in our controller except when rotating the upper body).

This is with roslaunch atlas_utils atlas_sandia_hands.launch

Doubled checked the URDF file, it has the 1e6 value in it.

issue.title: Feet drift when standing due commit #1565dbd

content.raw: It seems that alot of these problems are caused by the low ODE solver parameters. Instead of putting a bandaid on the gunshot wound, the correct solution is to increase the parameters.
content.html: It seems that alot of these problems are caused by the low ODE solver parameters. Instead of putting a bandaid on the gunshot wound, the correct solution is to increase the parameters.

issue.title: Feet drift when standing due commit #1565dbd

content.raw:
The proposed fixes give us the following values 

```
Hip Z rotation: ~ 0.0003 rad/second
Robot drift: ~ 1mm/minute
```

Walking seems to be unaffected, however we're in a transitional state with our walking controller so we only tested a simple straight line walk.

If these changes are merged we would consider the issue fixed for the VRC.
content.html:
The proposed fixes give us the following values 

Hip Z rotation: ~ 0.0003 rad/second
Robot drift: ~ 1mm/minute

Walking seems to be unaffected, however we're in a transitional state with our walking controller so we only tested a simple straight line walk.

If these changes are merged we would consider the issue fixed for the VRC.
